name: Geoffrey Moore
background: Geoffrey A. Moore is a Silicon Valley-based organizational consultant, venture capitalist, and author known for his seminal work on technology adoption and marketing. His 1991 book 'Crossing the Chasm' has sold over 1 million copies and introduced the 'chasm' concept in the technology adoption lifecycle, explaining why many high-tech products fail to transition from early adopters to mainstream markets. Moore holds degrees from Stanford and has consulted for numerous tech firms through his firm, The Chasm Institute.

principles.name: Beachhead Strategy
principles.description: Assemble overwhelming force for one specific market segment to establish dominance.
principles.falsification: When beachhead strategy leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Crossing the Chasm
principles.description: Identifies a critical gap between early adopters (visionaries) and the early majority (pragmatists). Success requires targeting a niche 'beachhead' segment to gain traction before expanding.
principles.falsification: When crossing the chasm leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Positioning for Pragmatists
principles.description: Early majority seeks references, standards, low risk. Avoid visionary hype.
principles.falsification: When positioning for pragmatists leads to worse outcomes than alternatives

principles.name: Technology Adoption Lifecycle
principles.description: Market segments: Innovators (2.5%), Early Adopters (13.5%), Early Majority (34%), Late Majority (34%), Laggards (16%). Each requires different strategies.
principles.falsification: When technology adoption lifecycle leads to worse outcomes than alternatives
